dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017

dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017 = <dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017_gen object>

The mass-ratio random variable of Moe and Stefano (2017)

As an instance of the rv_continuous class, dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017 object inherits from it a collection of generic methods (see below for the full list), and completes them with details specific for this particular distribution.

Methods

rvs(log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1, size=1, random_state=None)

Random variates.

pdf(x, log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Probability density function.

logpdf(x, log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Log of the probability density function.

cdf(x, log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Cumulative distribution function.

logcdf(x, log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Log of the cumulative distribution function.

sf(x, log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Survival function (also defined as 1 - cdf, but sf is sometimes more accurate).

logsf(x, log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Log of the survival function.

ppf(q, log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Percent point function (inverse of cdf — percentiles).

isf(q, log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Inverse survival function (inverse of sf).

moment(order, log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Non-central moment of the specified order.

stats(log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1, moments=’mv’)

Mean(‘m’), variance(‘v’), skew(‘s’), and/or kurtosis(‘k’).

entropy(log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

(Differential) entropy of the RV.

fit(data)

Parameter estimates for generic data. See scipy.stats.rv_continuous.fit for detailed documentation of the keyword arguments.

expect(func, args=(log10_period, primary_mass), loc=0, scale=1, lb=None, ub=None, conditional=False, **kwds)

Expected value of a function (of one argument) with respect to the distribution.

median(log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Median of the distribution.

mean(log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Mean of the distribution.

var(log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Variance of the distribution.

std(log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Standard deviation of the distribution.

interval(confidence, log10_period, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Confidence interval with equal areas around the median.

Notes

The probability density function for moe2017 is:

\[\begin{split}f_{Q|P, M_{1}}(q|p, m_{1}) = A_{Q}(p, m_{1}) \begin{cases} 0.3^{\delta(p, m_{1}) - \gamma(p, m_{1})}q^{\gamma(p, m_{1}]} &\text{if $q \in [0.1, 0.3]$}\\ q^{\delta(p, m_{1})} &\text{if $q \in (0.3, 0.95]$}\\ q^{\delta(p, m_{1})} + c_{\text{twin}}(p, m_{1}) &\text{if $q \in (0.95, 1]$} \end{cases}\end{split}\]

for mass ratio \(q \in [0, 1]\), period \(p \in [0.2, 8]\), and primary mass \(m_{1} \in [0.8, \infty)\), where the normalization constant, \(A_{Q}(p, m_{1})\), is such that

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} \dfrac{1}{A_{Q}(p, m_{1})} &= \begin{cases} 0.3^{\delta(p, m_{1}) - \gamma(p, m_{1})}\left(\ln(0.3) - \ln(0.1)\right) &\text{if $\gamma(p, m_{1}) = -1$}\\ \dfrac{0.3^{\delta(p, m_{1}) - \gamma(p, m_{1})}(0.3^{\gamma(p, m_{1}) + 1} - 0.1^{\gamma(p, m_{1}) + 1})}{\gamma(p, m_{1}) + 1} &\text{otherwise} \end{cases}\\ &\qquad + \begin{cases} - \ln(0.3) &\text{if $\delta(p, m_{1}) = -1$}\\ \dfrac{1 - 0.3^{\delta(p, m_{1}) + 1}}{\delta(p, m_{1}) + 1} &\text{otherwise} \end{cases}\\ &\qquad + 0.05c_{\text{twin}}(p, m_{1}) \end{split}\end{split}\]

for twin-excess constant

\[\begin{split}c_{\text{twin}}(p, m_{1}) = \begin{cases} \dfrac{F_{\text{twin}}(p, m_{1})\ln(1/0.3)}{0.05(1 - F_{\text{twin}}(p, m_{1}))} &\text{if $\gamma(p, m_{1}) = -1$}\\ \dfrac{F_{\text{twin}}(p, m_{1})(1 - 0.3^{\delta(p, m_{1}) + 1})}{0.05(\delta(p, m_{1}) + 1)(1 - F_{\text{twin}}(p, m_{1}))} &\text{otherwise} \end{cases}\end{split}\]

where the excess-twin fraction, \(F_{\text{twin}}\), is defined such that

\[F_{\text{twin}}(p, m_{1}) = \dfrac{\int_{0.95}^{1}c_{\text{twin}}(p, m_{1})\mathrm{d}\,q} {\int_{0.3}^{1}q^{\delta(p, m_{1})}\mathrm{d}\,q + \int_{0.95}^{1}c_{\text{twin}}(p, m_{1})\mathrm{d}\,q},\]

and is piecewise linear in \(\log_{10}(p)\) and given by

\[\begin{split}F_{\text{twin}}(p, m_{1}) = \begin{cases} f_{1}(p, m_{1}) &\text{if $\log_{10}(p) \in (0, 1]$}\\ f_{2}(p, m_{1}) &\text{if $\log_{10}(p) \in (1, \log_{10}(p_{\text{twin}}(m_{1}))]$}\\ 0 &\text{if $\log_{10}(p) \in (\log_{10}(p_{\text{twin}}(m_{1})), \infty)$}\\ \end{cases}\end{split}\]

where

\[\begin{split}f_{1}(p, m_{1}) &= 0.3 - 0.15\log_{10}(m_{1})\\ f_{2}(p, m_{1}) &= \left(1 - \dfrac{\log_{10}(p) - 1}{\log_{10}(p_{\text{twin}}(m_{1})) - 1}\right)f_{1}(p, m_{1})\end{split}\]

and where the logarithm of the excess-twin period is piecewise linear in primary mass:

\[\begin{split}\log_{10}(p_{\text{twin}}(m_{1})) = \begin{cases} 8 - m_{1} &\text{if $m_{1} \in (0, 6.5]$}\\ 1.5 &\text{if $m_{1} \in (6.5, \infty)$}. \end{cases}\end{split}\]

The functions \(\gamma\) and \(\delta\) are piecewise second-degree polynomials in \(\log_{10}(p)\) and \(m_{1}\) and are defined on the interval \([0.2, 8]\):

\[\begin{split}\gamma(p, m_{1}) = \begin{cases} \gamma_{1}(p, m_{1}) &\text{if $m_{1} \in (0.8, 1.2]$}\\ \gamma_{2}(p, m_{1}) &\text{if $m_{1} \in (1.2, 3.5)$}\\ \gamma_{3}(p, m_{1}) &\text{if $m_{1} = 3.5 $}\\ \gamma_{4}(p, m_{1}) &\text{if $m_{1} \in (3.5, 6]$}\\ \gamma_{5}(p, m_{1}) &\text{if $m_{1} \in (6, \infty)$} \end{cases}\end{split}\]

and

\[\begin{split}\delta(p, m_{1}) = \begin{cases} \delta_{1}(p, m_{1}) &\text{if $m_{1} \in (0.8, 1.2]$}\\ \delta_{2}(p, m_{1}) &\text{if $m_{1} \in (1.2, 3.5)$}\\ \delta_{3}(p, m_{1}) &\text{if $m_{1} = 3.5 $}\\ \delta_{4}(p, m_{1}) &\text{if $m_{1} \in (3.5, 6]$}\\ \delta_{5}(p, m_{1}) &\text{if $m_{1} \in (6, \infty)$} \end{cases}\end{split}\]

where

\[\begin{split}\gamma_{1}(p, m_{1}) &= 0.3\\ \gamma_{2}(p, m_{1}) &= \gamma_{1}(p, 1.2) + \dfrac{1}{2.3}(\gamma_{3}(p, 3.5) - \gamma_{1}(p, 1.2))(m_{1} - 1.2)\\ \gamma_{3}(p, m_{1}) &= \begin{cases} 0.2 &\text{ if $\log_{10}(p) \in [0.2, 2.5]$}\\ 0.2 - 0.3(\log_{10}(p) - 2.5) &\text{ if $\log_{10}(p) \in (2.5, 5.5]$}\\ -0.7 - 0.2(\log_{10}(p) - 5.5) &\text{ if $\log_{10}(p) \in (5.5, 8]$} \end{cases}\\ \gamma_{4}(p, m_{1}) &= \gamma_{3}(p, 3.5) + \dfrac{1}{2.5}(\gamma_{5}(p, 6) - \gamma_{3}(p, 3.5))(m_{1} - 3.5)\\ \gamma_{5}(p, m_{1}) &= \begin{cases} 0.1 &\text{ if $\log_{10}(p) \in [0.2, 1]$}\\ 0.1 - 0.15(\log_{10}(p) - 1) &\text{ if $\log_{10}(p) \in (1, 3]$}\\ -0.2 - 0.50(\log_{10}(p) - 3) &\text{ if $\log_{10}(p) \in (3, 5.6]$}\\ -1.5 &\text{ if $\log_{10}(p) \in (5.6, 8]$} \end{cases}\end{split}\]

and

\[\begin{split}\delta_{1}(p, m_{1}) &= \begin{cases} -0.5 &\text{if $\log_{10}(p) \in [0.2, 5]$}\\ -0.5 - 0.3(\log_{10}(p) - 5) &\text{if $\log_{10}(p) \in (5, 8]$} \end{cases}\\ \delta_{2}(p, m_{1}) &= \;\!\delta_{1}(p, 1.2) + \dfrac{1}{2.3}(\delta_{3}(p, 3.5) - \;\!\delta_{1}(p, 1.2))(m_{1} - 1.2)\\ \delta_{3}(p, m_{1}) &= \begin{cases} -0.5 &\text{if $\log_{10}(p) \in [0.2, 1]$}\\ -0.5 - 0.2(\log_{10}(p) - 1) &\text{if $\log_{10}(p) \in (1, 4.5]$}\\ -1.2 - 0.4(\log_{10}(p) - 4.5) &\text{if $\log_{10}(p) \in (4.5, 6.5]$}\\ -2 &\text{if $\log_{10}(p) \in (6.5, 8]$} \end{cases}\\ \delta_{4}(p, m_{1}) &= \;\!\delta_{3}(p, 3.5) + \dfrac{1}{2.5}(\delta_{5}(p, 6) - \;\!\delta_{3}(p, 3.5))(m_{1} - 3.5)\\ \delta_{5}(p, m_{1}) &= \begin{cases} -0.5 &\text{if $\log_{10}(p) \in [0.2, 1]$}\\ -0.5 - 0.9(\log_{10}(p) - 1) &\text{if $\log_{10}(p) \in (1, 2]$}\\ -1.4 - 0.3(\log_{10}(p) - 2) &\text{if $\log_{10}(p) \in (2, 4]$}\\ -2 &\text{if $\log_{10}(p) \in (4, 8]$}. \end{cases}\end{split}\]

moe2017 takes p and m as a shape parameter for \(p\), the period, and \(m_{1}\), the primary mass.

The probability density above is defined in the “standardized” form. To shift and/or scale the distribution use the loc and scale parameters. Specifically, mass_ratio.moe2017.pdf(x, log10_period, primary_mass, loc, scale) is identically equivalent to dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017.pdf(y, log10_period, primary_mass) / scale with y = (x - loc) / scale. Note that shifting the location of a distribution does not make it a “noncentral” distribution; noncentral generalizations of some distributions are available in separate classes.

References

Moe, Maxwell, and Rosanne Di Stefano. 2017. 'Mind your Ps and Qs: the interrelation between period (P) and mass-ratio (Q) distributions of binary stars.' The Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series 230 (2): 15.

Examples

>>> import numpy as np
>>> import dyad
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1)

Calculate the first four moments:

>>> log10_period, primary_mass = (2.56, 1.0)
>>> mean, var, skew, kurt = dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017.stats(log10_period, primary_mass, moments='mvsk')

Display the probability density function (pdf):

>>> x = np.linspace(dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017.ppf(0.01, log10_period, primary_mass),
...                 dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017.ppf(0.99, log10_period, primary_mass), 100)
>>> ax.plot(x, dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017.pdf(x, log10_period, primary_mass),
...        'r-', lw=5, alpha=0.6, label='dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017 pdf')

Alternatively, the distribution object can be called (as a function) to fix the shape, location and scale parameters. This returns a “frozen” RV object holding the given parameters fixed.

Freeze the distribution and display the frozen pdf:

>>> rv = dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017(log10_period, primary_mass)
>>> ax.plot(x, rv.pdf(x), 'k-', lw=2, label='frozen pdf')

Check accuracy of cdf and ppf:

>>> vals = dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017.ppf([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], log10_period, primary_mass)
>>> np.allclose([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017.cdf(vals, log10_period, primary_mass))
True

Generate random numbers:

>>> r = dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017.rvs(log10_period, primary_mass, size=1000)

And compare the histogram:

>>> ax.hist(r, density=True, bins='auto', histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.2)
>>> ax.set_xlim([x[0], x[-1]])
>>> ax.legend(loc='best', frameon=False)
>>> plt.show()
